title: Computational linguistics + data visualization: towards the interactive exploration of newspaper data
segmentation: So thanks.
First of all, I would like to thanks for inviting me and OK in this talk.

Will try to show you how to combine computational linguistics and data visualization in order to have platform platforms that can be used to navigate and analyze collections of textual data in general and newspaper data in particular.
I will try to focus on some important issues to be taken into account when developing such platforms.
And I hope these issues will be of interest for climbing community.
1st.

All I would like to share with you the same vocabulary, so I will start with some definitions so computational linguistics is the scientific study of language from a computational perspective, and the goal of computational linguistics is to create computational models of different kinds of linguistic phenomena and to make computers deal with some tasks related to human language.
It's an interdisciplinary field that covers many disciplines.

Of course, linguistics and computer science, but also statistics, machine learning, and there are many tasks that can be that are included in computational linguistics, such as information extraction, were sensitive valuation, natural language generations, and many others.
The love story between computational linguistics and newspapers, as is very long history and disease roots, at least in the 90, or maybe also before an.

For example, because we can say that the most extensively investigated domain in computational linguistics is the one of the news, and this means that many annotation standards has been developed taking into consideration the language of nutri ports.
And for example, the named entity annotation standard developed in the 90s in Message Understanding Conference.
But there are many others and this led to the annotation of many corpora in that includes nude news.
An for example in Italy, I've worked on the adaptation to Italian of a couple of these standards that were built upon the English language and also on the annotation of news data.
Following such standards to show you what I mean, what I said that there are many corpora available of news.
This is a table.
This is a list of available corpora available.
Linguistic resources annotated with temporal information in the news domain.
This is just temporary information.
Instruction is 1 just one of the many information extraction tasks, so you can imagine how many others.
Corporal News are available in computational linguistics and it's important to note that in this list, all the data are related to contemporary news.
So now historical news and historical data are included.

As for data visualization, data visualization is general term that covers all the visual methods that can be used to make to make to help people give significance to data and visualization are now widespread in many areas, and the interest for visualizations in humanities.
I was born well before the very famous book by Moretti graph Math Maps entries.
This is an example is a visualization made in 1861.
It was of course not digital.
Visualization was on paper and it's considered one of the most beautiful visualization of all the all the time.
It's it represents the invasion of Russia by Napoleon and his way back to Poland.
And in just one image there are a lot of information.
It's enough standard timeline with information about the movements of the troops from Poland to upstream back.
Information about the number of the soldiers, the temperature, the name, and the place of the bottles, all-in-one visualization.
And As for the relationship between data, visually visualization newspaper data well.
There are no visualization very common in newspaper.
There are many visual ways, many visual approaches to data journalism.
In Italy, for example, we have these wiki page by Corriere della Sera.
That is one of the most important newspaper in Italy and is the collaboration between the newspaper and research group in Politecnico in Milan that works on design and visualizations.
And every week there is.
A visualization, then try to explain important and complex social and political phenomenal in visual.
The context and of course, this is all these visualization are static are on newspaper.
So why trying to combine computational linguistics and data visualization?
Because we think that this combination can help improve the navigation through digital collection, and that can also improve the display of analysis.
Computational linguistic analysis, then can be very complex.
An so for for us it so for in our group we decide to develop online platforms for the Zend and during the creation of this platform you have to take into consideration many issues.
First of all, colors, reading and distant reading should be always strongly interconnected, so that the platform can be used for both qualitative and quantitative analysis.

This approach, that is called scalable reading is very useful also to allow the user to go back to the single documents and verify the source of the automatic analysis made by computational linguistics tools and also spotted some inconsistencies there because you know, that's no system is perfect, not even.
Part of speech tagger.
Then the platform should be flexible.
This means that should allow the comparison of different corpora or of different parts of the same corpora.
This allowed to undertake to identify some common patterns or also outliers distribution of information that is different, different textual sources.
Another important point is the interactivity.
So the outlet the output of the analysis should not be static should be interactive.
The queries should be real.
Time should be very really connected with the flexibility.
The temporal dimension is an essential essential information to be added to the platform.
This means that every information, every functionality should be time bounded and the queries should be refined thinking into consideration temporal constraints.
Danny, it's important to understand which are the final users.
Are they scholars?
Are the students?
Are they journalists?
This is important because these different audiences as different needs that can lead to the development or different functionalities.
Anyway, whatever the end users are, they probably will be people with no technical background.
This means that the platform should be easy to use and very intuitive.
Duty as much as possible.
This means also that it would be better to avoid the complex NLP algorithm because the user should understand what is below the interface an so to interpret the analysis.
The output of the analysis in the correct way.
And also to understand which are the criticism.
And last but not least, if you want to platform that works on historical data, you probably have to adapt the computational linguistic system you have.
You want to use because the language of the past, because as I said before, the majority of the systems we have today have been built on contemporary data.
We tried to deal with all these issues during the development of our platform that is called.
LCD is an acronym that stands for Analysis of Language and content in a digital environment.
The first prototype was released in 2013 an We continuously update it with new functionality.
New Hope, so new interfaces.
Thanks to collaboration with.
On historians and social scientists an you can see the general architecture.
So we have documents.
In input we have a pipeline of tools.
We developed an infant that several Kessler and then all the results are stored in the database and then visualized an we have online demo that is available in the demo.
You will not find newspaper data because of the Copyright issues I've mentioned on Monday.
But I will now show you some examples or on how it has been used or is currently used by scholars to perform analysis of newspaper data.
And I'll take some examples from 2 projects.
One project that is a collaboration with the social scientists.
It's about was about because now it's.
It's the IT finished last year.
